projects.name: Helmsman AI-Augmented Task Management
projects.description: Transform the basic task management system into a sophisticated AI-powered personal command center with energy-aware scheduling, intelligent task extraction, dependency management, and contextual assistance. Implements the complete Helmsman specification with enhanced Prisma schema, OpenAI integration, daily planning algorithm, and accessibility-compliant UI components.

projects.name: Calendar Sync Compatibility Resolution
projects.description: Complete the calendar sync re-enablement by resolving all compatibility issues between the legacy calendar sync implementation and the current codebase architecture, Prisma schema, and service interfaces. This project will restore full functionality to the enterprise-grade calendar synchronization system.

tasks.name: Enhance Prisma schema with Helmsman metadata fields
tasks.details:
Update the existing Prisma schema to support all Helmsman specification requirements including energy levels, focus types, task priorities, deadlines, dependencies, and user settings. This foundational change enables intelligent scheduling and AI-powered task management.

Files to modify:
- backend/prisma/schema.prisma: Add new enums (EnergyLevel, FocusType, TaskSource), extend Task model with metadata fields, create UserSettings model, add InteractionLog model for Mem0 integration
- backend/src/tasks/dto/: Create new DTOs for enhanced task creation/updates with metadata validation
- backend/src/users/dto/: Add UserSettings DTOs for energy patterns and preferences

Key schema additions:
- Task.energyLevel (enum: LOW, MEDIUM, HIGH)
- Task.focusType (enum: CREATIVE, TECHNICAL, ADMINISTRATIVE, SOCIAL) 
- Task.estimatedMinutes (integer, nullable)
- Task.priority (integer 1-5, default 3)
- Task.softDeadline and Task.hardDeadline (DateTime, nullable)
- Task.source (enum: SELF, BOSS, TEAM, AI_GENERATED)
- Task.aiSuggestion (text, nullable)
- UserSettings model with morningEnergyLevel, afternoonEnergyLevel, preferredWorkHours
- InteractionLog model for Mem0 context storage

Migration strategy: Add fields as nullable first, backfill with defaults, then apply constraints. This ensures zero-downtime deployment while maintaining data integrity for existing tasks.

tasks.name: Add nullable metadata columns to Task model
tasks.details:
Create Prisma migration files to add new enum types and nullable columns to the tasks table. This is the first phase of the schema enhancement that ensures zero-downtime deployment.

Add the following enums to schema.prisma:
- EnergyLevel: LOW, MEDIUM, HIGH
- FocusType: CREATIVE, TECHNICAL, ADMINISTRATIVE, SOCIAL  
- TaskSource: SELF, BOSS, TEAM, AI_GENERATED

Add nullable columns to Task model:
- energyLevel EnergyLevel?
- focusType FocusType?
- estimatedMinutes Int?
- priority Int? @default(3)
- softDeadline DateTime?
- hardDeadline DateTime?
- source TaskSource? @default(SELF)
- aiSuggestion String?

Generate migration with: npx prisma migrate dev --name add_task_metadata_fields
Test migration runs cleanly on existing data without errors or data loss.

tasks.name: Create UserSettings and InteractionLog models
tasks.details:
Create UserSettings and InteractionLog models in Prisma schema to support user energy patterns and Mem0 integration.

UserSettings model: userId, morningEnergyLevel, afternoonEnergyLevel, preferredWorkHours, focusSessionLength, workStartTime, workEndTime, timestamps.

InteractionLog model: id, userId, interactionType, input, output, metadata Json, timestamp for Mem0 semantic memory.

Generate migration: npx prisma migrate dev --name add_user_settings_and_interaction_logs
Test both models can be created and queried without foreign key constraint issues.

tasks.name: Create data migration to backfill task metadata
tasks.details:
Create safe data migration scripts to backfill existing tasks with sensible defaults for the new metadata fields. This ensures all existing user data remains functional while gaining the benefits of enhanced scheduling.

Create backfill script in backend/prisma/scripts/backfill-task-metadata.ts:
- Set energyLevel = MEDIUM for all existing tasks (safe neutral default)
- Set focusType = ADMINISTRATIVE for existing tasks (conservative default)
- Set priority = 3 for all existing tasks (middle priority)
- Set source = SELF for all existing tasks (user-created assumption)
- Leave deadlines and aiSuggestion as null (no assumptions about timing)
- Preserve all existing task data (title, description, completed, dueDate, etc.)

Verification steps:
- Count tasks before/after migration to ensure no data loss
- Verify all non-nullable fields have values
- Test that existing API endpoints continue to work
- Create rollback script to remove new fields if needed

Run backfill after schema migration but before applying NOT NULL constraints. Include comprehensive logging and progress tracking for large datasets.

tasks.name: Implement energy-aware daily planning algorithm
tasks.details:
Implement the core daily planning algorithm that generates optimized schedules based on task metadata, user energy patterns, dependencies, and time constraints. This is the heart of the Helmsman intelligent scheduling system.

Create backend/src/planning/daily-planner.service.ts with:
- Task scoring algorithm considering priority, deadlines, energy match, focus batching
- Energy-aware scheduling that matches high-energy tasks to morning slots
- Dependency resolution to ensure blocked tasks aren't scheduled
- Time slot generation based on user preferences and existing commitments
- Focus type batching for cognitive efficiency (group similar work)
- Overcommitment detection and task deferral logic

Algorithm components:
- calculateTaskScore(task, timeSlot, userSettings): scoring function
- resolveTaskDependencies(tasks): filter out blocked tasks
- generateTimeSlots(date, userSettings, commitments): available time windows
- assignTasksToSlots(tasks, slots): greedy assignment with optimization
- OptimizationResult with energyOptimization and focusOptimization scores

API endpoint: GET /api/plans/today?date=YYYY-MM-DD
Returns DailyPlan with scheduleBlocks, unscheduledTasks, optimization metrics

Include comprehensive unit tests with various scenarios: normal day, overcommitted, all tasks blocked, empty schedule, user with different energy patterns.

tasks.name: Implement task scoring algorithm with weighted factors
tasks.details:
Enhanced the calculateTaskScore function in daily-planner.service.ts with comprehensive weighted factor implementation and robust edge case handling.

**Implementation Summary:**
âœ… **Weighted Factor Algorithm**: Implemented 4-factor scoring system with correct weights:
- Priority weight (40%): priority * 8 points (max 40)
- Deadline urgency (30%): up to 30 points, higher for tasks due soon/overdue
- Energy level match (20%): HIGH=20pts, MEDIUM=15pts, LOW=10pts  
- Focus type efficiency (10%): CREATIVE/TECHNICAL=8pts, ADMINISTRATIVE=6pts, SOCIAL=10pts

âœ… **Score Normalization**: Ensures return values stay within 0-100 range as specified

âœ… **Comprehensive Edge Case Handling**:
- Null/undefined task protection with graceful fallback
- Invalid priority validation (1-5 range) with default medium priority
- Invalid/missing deadline handling with proper date validation
- Overdue task handling (past deadlines get maximum urgency score)
- Missing/invalid energy level with fallback to MEDIUM default
- Missing/invalid focus type with fallback to ADMINISTRATIVE default

âœ… **Backward Compatibility**: Maintained existing function signature and return structure used by scoreTasks method

âœ… **Quality Validation**:
- ESLint compliance confirmed (no new lint errors in modified file)
- All 9 DailyPlannerService tests passing including edge case scenarios
- Enhanced JSDoc documentation explaining weighted factors and edge cases

**Technical Details:**
- File: `backend/src/planning/daily-planner.service.ts`
- Function: `calculateTaskScore(task: Task, targetDate: Date, userSettings: UserSettings)`
- Return: Object with total score (0-100) and component breakdowns
- Edge Cases: Handles invalid data, missing metadata, past deadlines, circular dependencies

The implementation provides robust task scoring for the Helmsman AI scheduling algorithm with proper error handling and performance optimization.

tasks.name: Build dependency resolution engine
tasks.details:
Successfully implemented comprehensive dependency resolution engine with robust error handling and detailed blocking reasons.

**Implementation Summary:**
Built complete dependency resolution system that identifies ready vs blocked tasks with comprehensive error handling. The new `resolveTaskDependencies` function provides structured results with detailed blocking reasons, handles edge cases like orphaned dependencies, and maintains backward compatibility.

**Key Features Delivered:**
âœ… Structured return with ready/blocked task arrays and counts
âœ… Detailed blocking reasons (incomplete_dependency, orphaned_dependency, circular_dependency, missing_dependency)  
âœ… Robust error handling for missing tasks and database failures
âœ… Comprehensive logging for debugging and monitoring
âœ… Backward compatibility with existing dependency detection logic
âœ… Full test coverage with edge case validation

**Files Modified:**
- `backend/src/planning/types.ts`: Added `DependencyResolutionResult`, `BlockedTask`, `BlockingReason` interfaces
- `backend/src/planning/daily-planner.service.ts`: Added `resolveTaskDependencies` method with comprehensive logic
- `backend/src/planning/daily-planner.service.spec.ts`: Added 3 comprehensive test cases

**Verification Results:**
- **Lint:** `pnpm lint` - Clean (0 new errors)
- **Tests:** `pnpm test` - All passing (12/12 tests, +3 new tests)
- **Build:** TypeScript compilation successful

**API Usage:**
```typescript
const result = await dailyPlannerService.resolveTaskDependencies(tasks);
// Returns structured result with ready/blocked tasks and detailed reasons
```

Production-ready dependency resolution engine now available for the Helmsman AI scheduling system.

tasks.name: Implement security hardening and audit logging
tasks.details:
Implement security hardening measures including rate limiting, audit logging, and data encryption to protect the Helmsman system in production. This ensures safe handling of user data and AI interactions.

Create backend/src/security/rate-limiting.middleware.ts:
- Redis-based rate limiting with different limits per endpoint type
- AI endpoints: 10 requests/minute (expensive operations)
- Task operations: 60 requests/minute (standard CRUD)
- Authentication endpoints: 5 requests/minute (prevent brute force)
- Rate limit headers in responses (X-RateLimit-Limit, X-RateLimit-Remaining)

Implement audit logging in backend/src/security/audit-logger.service.ts:
- Log all task modifications with user ID, action, and changes
- Track AI interactions with input/output sanitization
- Record authentication events and permission changes
- Structured logging with correlation IDs for tracing
- Retention policy and log rotation

Data encryption service in backend/src/security/encryption.service.ts:
- Encrypt sensitive data at rest (AI suggestions, user preferences)
- Use AES-256-GCM with proper key management
- Environment-based encryption keys with rotation support
- Encrypt/decrypt methods with proper error handling

Security headers middleware:
- CORS configuration for production domains
- Content Security Policy headers
- XSS protection and clickjacking prevention
- HTTPS enforcement and security headers

Include security testing with automated vulnerability scanning and penetration testing scenarios.

Create CalendarView.tsx (main container), CalendarHeader.tsx (navigation buttons, view switcher), CalendarGrid.tsx (responsive grid layout). 

Daily: 24-hour timeline, 30-min slots. Weekly: 7-day grid, hourly precision. Monthly: date cell grid. All views responsive with CSS Grid.

Navigation: prev/next/today buttons, keyboard arrows, smooth view transitions. Use React hooks for currentDate/selectedView state.

API integration: useCalendarData.ts hook, loading states, error boundaries. Map backend CalendarEvent to frontend format.

tasks.name: Implement Drag-and-Drop Task Scheduling
tasks.details:
Implement drag-and-drop task scheduling with @dnd-kit library and visual feedback.

Install @dnd-kit/core, @dnd-kit/sortable, @dnd-kit/utilities. Create DragWrapper component for draggable events/tasks.

Drag functionality: 300ms delay to prevent accidental drags, visual feedback during drag (ghost element, drop zones). Drop validation: prevent conflicts, time slot availability checking.

ADHD-friendly features: Clear drag handles, obvious drop zones, confirmation dialog for significant time changes, smooth animations with respect for reduced motion.

Integration: Update CalendarEvent and TimeSlot components with drag capabilities. Connect to backend API for persisting schedule changes.

Files: DragWrapper.tsx, useDragAndDrop.ts hook, drag-styles.module.css. Update existing components for drag support.

Success: Smooth dragging, clear feedback, drop validation works, no accidental drags, animations respect motion preferences, schedule updates persist.

Testing: jest-axe test suite, keyboard navigation tests, screen reader compatibility.

Files: calendar-a11y.ts utilities, accessibility tests, ARIA constants. Update all components with a11y attributes.

Success: WCAG 2.2 AA verified, full keyboard navigation, screen reader compatible, focus management, high contrast support, axe tests pass.

Test files: calendar-view.e2e.ts, calendar-navigation.e2e.ts, calendar-drag-drop.e2e.ts, calendar-accessibility.e2e.ts.

The 87 test failures are **Content Alignment Issues**, not infrastructure problems:

**Test Expectation vs Reality:**
- Tests expect: `getByRole('button', { name: /daily planning/i })`
- Reality: Dashboard shows "Loading your daily plan..." (status message, not button)
- Tests expect: `data-testid` attributes (e.g., `[data-testid="dashboard-title"]`)
- Reality: Sophisticated Helmsman dashboard with different class structure

**Content Mismatch Examples:**
1. **Daily Planning Tests**: Looking for clickable "Daily Planning" button, but dashboard shows loading state
2. **Test Selectors**: Expect `data-testid` attributes, actual UI uses different CSS classes
3. **Navigation**: Tests expect basic structure, actual UI has sophisticated ADHD-optimized features

- Sophisticated Helmsman dashboard with "AI-powered productivity workspace"
- Energy level filters (High/Medium/Low Energy)
- Focus type filters (Creative/Technical/Administrative/Social)
- AI Assistant with task extraction capabilities
- Calendar integration
- Performance metrics without infinite render loops

tasks.name: Implement Notification History and Persistence
tasks.details:
Build notification persistence system for delivery tracking, history viewing, and read/unread status. Completes WebSocket infrastructure with database persistence.

**Backend (4h):** 
- Create notification-history.service.ts with saveNotificationToDatabase(), markAsRead(), getHistory(), getUnreadCount()
- Update notifications.service.ts to persist all notifications with delivery status
- Enhance Prisma Notification model: add deliveryStatus, readAt, retryCount, notificationType, metadata fields
- Create API endpoints: GET /notifications/history, PUT /notifications/:id/read, GET /notifications/unread-count

**Database Schema:**
```sql
ALTER TABLE notifications ADD delivery_status VARCHAR(20) DEFAULT 'pending';
ALTER TABLE notifications ADD read_at TIMESTAMP;
ALTER TABLE notifications ADD notification_type VARCHAR(50);
ALTER TABLE notifications ADD metadata JSONB;
```

**Frontend (2h):**
- Update WebSocketContext.tsx: add acknowledgment, sync read status
- Create useNotificationHistory.ts hook: fetchHistory(), markAsRead(), pagination
- Add infinite scroll for large notification lists

**Success Criteria:**
- All notifications persist to database with tracking
- Users view paginated notification history with filtering
- Read/unread status syncs frontend/backend  
- Delivery failures retry with exponential backoff
- Cleanup service maintains database size

tasks.name: Add User Notification Preferences System
tasks.details:
Create granular user notification preferences system allowing per-notification-type settings, quiet hours, and audio/visual customization. Integrates with existing UserSettings model.

**Backend (2h):**
- Extend UserSettings model: add notificationPreferences JSONB field with default settings
- Create notification-preferences.service.ts: getPreferences(), updatePreferences(), validateSettings()
- Add preference checking to notifications.service.ts before sending notifications
- Support per-type settings: task-updates, calendar-sync, deadline-reminders, conflicts
- Implement quiet hours: suppress notifications during user-defined time windows
- Create API endpoints: GET/PUT /api/users/notification-preferences

**Notification Preference Schema:**
```json
{
  "globalEnabled": true,
  "types": {
    "task-update": {"enabled": true, "urgencyThreshold": "medium"},
    "calendar-sync": {"enabled": true, "urgencyThreshold": "low"},
    "deadline-reminder": {"enabled": true, "urgencyThreshold": "low"}
  },
  "quietHours": {"start": "22:00", "end": "08:00"},
  "audioEnabled": false,
  "batchingEnabled": true,
  "batchInterval": 30000
}
```

**Frontend (2h):**
- Create NotificationPreferences.tsx component with toggle switches and time pickers
- Update useNotifications.ts hook to respect user preferences
- Add preferences tab to user settings page
- Real-time preview of notification behavior with current settings
- Integrate with existing ADHD-friendly notification features

**Success Criteria:**
- Users customize notification types individually
- Quiet hours suppress non-urgent notifications
- Audio/visual preferences work across all notification types
- Settings persist and sync across user sessions
- ADHD-friendly defaults maintain usability

tasks.name: Create Notification Templates and Personalization
tasks.details:
Create rich notification templates with personalization and smart formatting. Replaces basic text with engaging, contextual messages.

**Backend (2h):**
- Create notification-templates.service.ts with Handlebars template engine
- Define templates: task-update, calendar-sync, deadline-reminder, conflict-alert
- Add user context: name, preferences, energy patterns, recent activity
- Smart formatting: relative time, priority indicators, personalized greetings
- Template validation with fallback to basic text on errors

**Template Examples:**
```handlebars
"{{greeting}} {{userName}}! ðŸ“ Your {{priorityEmoji}} task '{{taskTitle}}' {{actionPast}}."
"â° {{urgencyEmoji}} {{userName}}, '{{taskTitle}}' is due {{relativeTime}}."
```

**Frontend (2h):**
- Update notification components for rich HTML content
- Add template previews in settings with user's actual data
- Support emoji, formatting, personalized messages
- Maintain ADHD-friendly design: clear hierarchy, not overwhelming
- Add notification sound selection with preview

**Personalization:**
- Time-aware greetings (Good morning/afternoon)
- Energy level context ("Since you're high-energy...")
- Progress encouragement ("You've completed 3 tasks today!")
- Contextual suggestions based on current activity

**Success Criteria:**
- All notifications use rich, personalized templates
- Graceful fallback to basic text on errors
- Template preview with user's real data
- ADHD-friendly clarity maintained
- Template rendering under 10ms per notification

tasks.name: Enhance Notification Queue with Priority Management
tasks.details:
Enhance notification queue with intelligent priority management, smart batching, and delivery optimization for improved user experience.

**Backend (2h):**
- Update notifications.service.ts with priority-based queue system
- Implement notification priority levels: critical, high, medium, low
- Add intelligent batching: group related notifications (same task, same type)
- Create delivery optimization: analyze user activity patterns for best timing
- Add queue performance monitoring: track delivery success rates, timing metrics
- Implement notification coalescing: merge similar notifications to reduce noise

**Priority Rules:**
- Critical: Security alerts, system failures (immediate delivery)
- High: Deadline reminders <2hrs, calendar conflicts (5min delay max)
- Medium: Task updates, calendar sync (30min batching)
- Low: Weekly summaries, tips (daily batching)

**Smart Batching Logic:**
- Group notifications by type and timeframe
- Collapse multiple task updates into single summary
- Batch calendar events from same sync operation
- Respect ADHD-friendly limits: max 3 notifications per batch

**Frontend (1h):**
- Update notification display to show batched items expandably
- Add priority indicators with visual cues (colors, icons)
- Show delivery optimization status in debug mode
- Maintain focus mode compatibility with new priority system

**Performance Monitoring:**
- Track queue depth and processing time
- Monitor notification delivery success rates
- Analyze user engagement with different priority levels
- Generate reports for notification effectiveness

**Success Criteria:**
- Critical notifications deliver immediately
- Batching reduces notification volume by 60%
- User engagement improves with priority-based delivery
- Queue processing stays under 100ms average
- ADHD-friendly batching respects cognitive load limits

tasks.name: Fix Prisma Schema Compatibility - conflictData Type
tasks.details:
Update the Prisma schema compatibility issues where the calendar sync code expects object types for conflictData but the current schema expects string. The integration tests show conflictData being used as objects ({ localValue: 'Local Title', remoteValue: 'Remote Title' }) but the schema defines it as string | null. This requires either updating the schema to support JSON objects or modifying the code to serialize/deserialize the data properly.

Goals:
- Analyze current Prisma schema for CalendarSyncConflict model
- Determine if conflictData should be JSON object or string
- Update either schema or code to maintain consistency
- Ensure test data structures align with schema expectations

Expected Outcomes:
- conflictData field properly typed and functional
- Integration tests can create conflict records without type errors
- Data serialization/deserialization working correctly

tasks.name: Fix Service Interface Mismatches
tasks.details:
Fix service interface mismatches where the calendar sync services expect methods that don't exist or have changed signatures in the current codebase. Key issues include:

1. GraphAuthService.getValidAccessToken() doesn't exist (should be getAccessToken())
2. GraphAuthService.isTokenValid() method missing from current interface
3. CalendarSyncService missing methods like getSyncHistory(), testSyncCapabilities(), getSyncMetrics()
4. ConflictResolver.detectConflicts() method signature changed (missing lastSyncTime parameter)
5. ConflictInfo interface has changed - missing properties like hasConflict, conflictTypes, localModified, remoteModified, details, suggestedResolution

Goals:
- Update all service method calls to match current interfaces
- Add missing methods to services or remove calls to them
- Update type interfaces to match current implementations
- Ensure dependency injection works correctly

Expected Outcomes:
- All service method calls compile without errors
- Service interfaces are consistent across the codebase
- Dependency injection resolves all services correctly
- No method signature mismatches

tasks.name: Fix Prisma Enum Mismatches
tasks.details:
Resolve Prisma enum mismatches where the calendar sync code references enum values that don't exist in the current schema. Key issues include:

1. CalendarConflictType enum missing values: DESCRIPTION, END_TIME, LOCATION, ALL_DAY, RECURRENCE
2. CalendarConflictResolution enum has 'MERGED' instead of 'MERGE'
3. Test code uses enum values that don't match current schema definitions

Goals:
- Analyze current Prisma schema enum definitions
- Compare with calendar sync code enum usage
- Update either schema enums or code to align
- Ensure all enum references are valid

Expected Outcomes:
- All enum value references compile without errors
- Consistent enum definitions across schema and code
- Test data uses valid enum values
- No missing enum value errors

tasks.name: Fix Test Framework Compatibility

Expected Outcomes:
